CS 1100.description: Small group discussions with first year students are led by one or more faculty members and include a variety of foundational, motivational, and topical subjects for computationalist.
CS 1100.title: Freshman Leap Seminar

CS 1171.description: For students with a solid introductory computing background needing to demonstrate proficiency in the MATLAB language.
CS 1171.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 15XX Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 13X1 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of D
CS 1171.title: Computing in MATLAB

CS 1301.description: Introduction to computing principles and programming practices with an emphasis on the design, construction and implementation of problem solutions use of software tools.
CS 1301.title: Intro to Computing

CS 1315.description: Introduction to computation (algorithmic thinking, data structures, data transformation and processing, and programming) in a media and communication context. Credit not awarded for both CS 4452 and CS 1315.
CS 1315.title: Intro Media Computation

CS 1316.description: Modeling the structure of media (e.g., music, graphical scenes) using dynamic data structures. Designing objects as encapsulations of structure and behavior. Algorithms for simulating objects. May not be taken for credit by students who have credit for CS 1322.
CS 1316.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of D

CS 1331.description: Introduction to techniques and methods of object-oriented programming such an encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism. Emphasis on software development and individual programming skills.
CS 1331.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1321 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of C
CS 1331.title: Intro-Object Orient Prog

CS 1332.description: Computer data structures and algorithms in the context of object-oriented programming. Focus on software development towards applications.
CS 1332.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1322 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 1332.title: Data Struct & Algorithms

CS 1371.description: Foundations of computing with an introduction to design and analysis of algorithms and an introduction to design and construction of programs for engineering problem-solving.
CS 1371.title: Computing for Engineers

CS 1372.description: Design, analysis and implementation of programs for engineering problem-solving using ANSI Standard C, with an introduction to C++.
CS 1372.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1171 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of C
CS 1372.title: Program Design for Engrs

CS 2050.description: Proof methods, strategy, correctness of algorithms over discrete structures. Induction and recursion. Complexity and order of growth. Number theoretic principles and algorithms. Counting and computability. Credit not allowed for both CS 2050 and CS 2051.
CS 2050.title: Intro Discrete Math CS

CS 2051.description: Proof methods, strategy, correctness of algorithms over discrete structures. Induction and recursion. Complexity and order of growth. Number theoretic principles and algorithms. Counting and computability. Credit not allowed for both CS 2051 and CS 2050.

CS 2110.description: An introduction to basic computer hardware, machine language, assembly language, and C programming.
CS 2110.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C

CS 2200.description: A broad exposure to computer system structure and networking including software abstractions in operating systems for orchestrating the usage of the computing resources.
CS 2200.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or (Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2020 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2035 Minimum Grade of C)
CS 2200.title: Systems and Networks

CS 2261.description: Controlling the interface between hardware and software in media devices. Machine-level programming (e.g., in C) to create graphics, generate sound, and support user interaction.
CS 2261.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 2261.title: Media Device Architectur

CS 2316.description: Reading, manipulating, and exporting data for engineering, business, and scientific applications. Covers GUI's, File I/O, basic SQL, and web scraping. Emphasis on software development.
CS 2316.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of D
CS 2316.title: Data Input/Manipulation

CS 2335.description: Methods for solving large programming problems. Techniques for quality assurance, managing programs, working in teams, analyzing problems, and producing effective solutions.
CS 2335.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C
CS 2335.title: Software Practicum

CS 2340.description: Object-oriented programming methods for dealing with large programs. Focus on quality processes, effective debugging techniques, and testing to assure a quality product.
CS 2340.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1372 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1316 Minimum Grade of C
CS 2340.title: Objects and Design

CS 2345.description: This course presents important programming principles that should be considered when using a non-automatic memory management complex language (such as C++). Templating, generic programming, resource acquisition is initialization (RAII), and smart pointers are a few examples. Credit not awarded for both CS 2345 and ECE 2036.
CS 2345.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C and ( (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of C) or (Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2020 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2035 Minimum Grade of C) )
CS 2345.title: Adv Practical O-O Prog

CS 2600.description: Introduction to the representation and manipulation of complex symbolic and sub-symbolic information.
CS 2600.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of C
CS 2600.title: Knowledge Rep & Process

CS 2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CS 2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.
CS 2699.title: Undergraduate Research

CS 2701.description: Elements of technology venture creation including opportunity identification and validation, ideation, customer discovery, markey analysis, minimum viable product development, business models, intellectual property, and capital raises. Cross-listed with COE 2701.
CS 2701.title: Startup Lab

CS 3001.description: Examines the role and impact of information and communication technology in society, with emphasis on ethical, professional, and public policy issues.
CS 3001.title: Computing & Society

CS 3101.description: Students will learn how computer-science-based ventures are developed. The course is project-based. Students propose, analylze, pitch, design, implement, package and market web-2.0 and virtual-world-based products and services.
CS 3101.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3101.title: Comp Sci Ventures

CS 3210.description: Operating systems concepts, including multi-threading, scheduling, synchronization, communication, and access control. Projects will cover design and implementation of several operating systems components.
CS 3210.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3210.title: Design-Operating Systems

CS 3220.description: Principles in pipelined processor design, with emphasis on the need for a close interaction between code generation and architecture.
CS 3220.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C) and Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2031 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3220.title: Processor Design

CS 3240.description: Interpreters as abstract machines and the tools used to construct them, such as scanners and parsers. An introduction to models of computation as embodied by different programming languages. Limits of and relationships between these models.
CS 3240.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3240.title: Languages and Computation

CS 3251.description: Introduction to problems in computer networking, including error recovery, medium access, routing, flow control, and transport. Emphasis on current best practice. Includes programming of networked applications.
CS 3251.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3251.title: Computer Networking I

CS 3300.description: Team-based project class to introduce and apply software engineering principles and practices.
CS 3300.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3300.title: Intro to Software Engr

CS 3311.description: Part 1 of a 2 semester project design and implementation sequence conjoined with Technical Communications. Prepare requirements, design and project plans. Develop a basic prototype of the desired system. Project is completed in CS 3312-Project Implementation. Credit will not be awared for CS 3311 and CS 4911.
CS 3311.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3311.title: Project Design

CS 3312.description: The second part of a 2 semester project design and implementation sequence conjoined with Technical Communications. Implement a project designed in CS 3311. Credit will not be awarded for CS 3312 and CS 4911.
CS 3312.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level LMC 3432 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3312.title: Project Implementation

CS 3451.description: Geometric constuctions; transformations; perception; reflection models; photorealistic; non-photorealistic, and image-based rendering; rendering software and API's; triangle-mesh processing; graphic acceleration; user-interaction, design and animation.
CS 3451.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2605 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2401 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2411 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 24X1 Minimum Grade of T or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2551 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2550 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2561 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2X51 Minimum Grade of T) and ( (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of C) or (Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2020 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2035 Minimum Grade of C) ) and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C)
CS 3451.title: Computer Graphics

CS 3510.description: Basic techniques of design and analysis of efficient algorithms for standard computational problems. NP-Completeness. Credit not allowed for both CS 3510 and CS 3511.
CS 3510.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2050 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2051 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2106 Minimum Grade of C) and Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3510.title: Dsgn&Analysis-Algorithms

CS 3511.description: Techniques of design and analysis of efficient algorithms for standard computational problems. NP-Completeness Project. Credit not allowed for both CS 3511 and CS 3510.
CS 3511.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2050 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2051 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2106 Minimum Grade of C) and Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C or (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3012 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3022 Minimum Grade of D)
CS 3511.title: Algorithms Honors

CS 3600.description: An introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning. Topics include intelligent system design methodologies, search and problem solving, supervised and reinforced learning.
CS 3600.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3600.title: Intro-Artificial Intell

CS 3630.description: Covers fundamental problems and leading solutions for computer and robot perception and action from the point of view of autonomous robot navigation.
CS 3630.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3630.title: Intro-Perception&Robotic

CS 3651.description: Hands-on course teaching the fundamentals of electronics of electrical and mechanical prototyping.
CS 3651.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2031 Minimum Grade of C
CS 3651.title: Prototyping Intelligent Device

CS 3743.description: Analysis of emerging technologies and their impacts for firm practice, market practice, policy, and society. Credit not allowed for both CS 3743 and MGT 3743 or ME 3743.
CS 3743.title: Emerging Technologies

CS 3744.description: Analysis of the managerial challenges of the product development process.
CS 3744.title: Mangn Prod Serv Tech Dev

CS 3750.description: Human computer interface is considered in terms of user-system compatibility. Concepts in human factors and interface design are covered in relation to capabilities of both humans and computers. Crosslisted with PSYC 3750.
CS 3750.title: User Interface Design

CS 3790.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with PST, PSYC, and ISYE 3790.
CS 3790.title: Intro-Cognitive Science

CS 4001.description: Examines the role and impact of information and communication technology in society, with emphasis on ethical, professional, and public policy issues. Credit not allowed for both CS 4001 and 4002.
CS 4001.title: Computing & Society

CS 4002.description: Examines the role and impact of robotics, distributed sensing and actuation, ubiquitous computing and related technology in society, emphasizing ethical, professional and public policy issues. Credit not allowed for both CS 4001 and 4002
CS 4002.title: Robots and Society

CS 4003.description: This course covers various Artificial Intelligence and bias mitigation techniques that can be used to counterbalance the potential misuse and abuse of learning from data.
CS 4003.title: AI Ethics and Society

CS 4005.description: Students will explore new paradigms in how content is created, distributed, and consumed, with hands-on demos of next-generation computing technologies.
CS 4005.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2316 Minimum Grade of D
CS 4005.title: Next Gen Computing Tech

CS 4010.description: Provides an introduction to copyrights, patents, trade secrets, trademarks, and commercial law pertaining to computer software and hardware.
CS 4010.title: Intro to Computer Law

CS 4052.description: An introductory course on the development life cycle of business information systems. It covers analysis and design tools and methodology. Credit not allowed for both CS 4052 and MGT 4045.
CS 4052.title: Systems Analysis& Design

CS 4057.description: Business processes are the mechanisms by which work is organized and performed. This course covers the analysis of business technology. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4057 and MGT 4057.
CS 4057.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level MGT 2200 Minimum Grade of D
CS 4057.title: Bus Process Analy&Design

CS 4210.description: Operating system abstractions and their implementations, multi-threading, efficient inter-address communication, high-level synchronization, introduction to multi-processor and distributed operating systems, real-time systems. Credit is not awarded for both CS 4210 and CS 6210.
CS 4210.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3210 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4210.title: Adv Operating Systems

CS 4220.description: Design principles, programming techniques, and case studies of embedded real-time systems. Interface techniques and devices. Representations and reasoning about physical processes.Credit not awarded for both CS 4220 and CS 6235.
CS 4220.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4220.title: Embedded Systems

CS 4233.description: The objective of this course is to develop an in-depth understanding of the design, implementation, and evaluation of modern parallel computers. Credit not allowed for both CS 4233 and CS 7110.
CS 4233.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3210 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4233.title: Parallel Comp Arch

CS 4235.description: Terms/concepts, threats, controls; problem definition; comprehensive information security model; security for operating systems, databases, network/distributed systems; administering security; legal/ethical/policy issues. Credit not allowed for both CS 4235 and CS 6035.
CS 4235.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4235.title: Intro to Info Security

CS 4237.description: Fundamental concepts and principles of computer security, operating system and database security, secret key and public key cryptographic algorithms, hash functions, authentication, firewalls and intrusion detection systems, IPSec ad VPN, and wireless security.
CS 4237.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3251 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4237.title: Comp & Network Security

CS 4240.description: Study of techniques for the design and implementation of compilers, interpreters, and program analyzers, with consideration of the particular characteristics of widely used programming languages.
CS 4240.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4240.title: Compilers & Interpreters

CS 4245.description: Computational techniques for analysis of large, complex datasets, covering fundamental aspects as well as modern data mining and analysis techniques. Cross-listed with ISYE 4245.
CS 4245.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2605 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2401 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2411 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 24X1 Minimum Grade of D) and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1372 Minimum Grade of C)
CS 4245.title: Intro Data Mining & Anal

CS 4251.description: Principles of computer networks, including medium access, ARQ protocols, routing, congestion avoidance, and control. Emphasis on design options and tradeoffs. Includes significant network application programming.
CS 4251.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3251 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4251.title: Computer Networking II

CS 4255.description: Introduction to SNMP-based network management. Practical application to network and system management including hands-on lab practice.
CS 4255.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3251 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4255.title: Intro-Network Management

CS 4260.description: Study of telecommunication systems emphasizing functional roles of the various portions of the system and how various functional components support and interact with one another.
CS 4260.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3215 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3225 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3770 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 3770 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CEE 3770 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 2028 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3670 Minimum Grade of D) and Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4260.title: Telecommunications Sys

CS 4261.description: This course provides an introduction to mobile applications and services with an emphasis on voice and data service integration in modern commercial networks.
CS 4261.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4261.title: Mobile Apps & Svcs

CS 4270.description: Detailed study of the principles of data transmission systems and their performance, reinforced by laboratory exercises.
CS 4270.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3251 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4270.title: Data Communications Lab

CS 4280.description: Overview of telecommunication regulation at the federal, state, and judicial levels; review of FCC policies and restrictions on Bell operating companies under the AT&T Consent Agreement.
CS 4280.title: Survey-Telecom & the Law

CS 4290.description: Topics concerning the hardware design of computer systems. Advanced techniques in high-performance pipelined central processing units. Memory and I/O systems. Parallel processors including shared-memory multiprocessors and cluster computers. Credit is not allowed for both CS 4290 and any of the following courses: CS 6290, ECE 4100, ECE 6100.
CS 4290.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4290.title: Advanced Computer Org

CS 4320.description: The course will provide students with an overall context in which software systems are developed from the viewpoint of processes that support development. Software engineering is described as the set of activities developers engage in to create high-quality products within schedule and budget constraints.
CS 4320.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3300 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4320.title: Software Processes

CS 4330.description: Software engineering methods specific to classes of applications or systems, including information systems and embedded, real-time systems.
CS 4330.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3300 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4330.title: Software Applications

CS 4342.description: Methods and principles for program generation, testing, and managing the evolution of software systems.
CS 4342.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3300 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4342.title: Software Generation

CS 4365.description: A survey of basic software tools and techniques used in mission-critical systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying enterprise computing. Credit not allowed for both 4365 and CS 6365.
CS 4365.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3210 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4365.title: Intro Enterprise Comp

CS 4392.description: Fundamentals of programming language design and theory. Topics include formal semantics and type systems for imperative, functional, and parallel languages; lambda calculus and its variants; the Curry-Howard Correspondence; techniques for proving language properties and verifying program specifications.
CS 4392.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4392.title: Programming Languages

CS 4400.description: Comprehensive coverage of mainstream database concepts such as the entity-relationship model, relational databases, query languages, and database design methodology. Includes a project. Credit not allowed for both CS 4400 and CS 6402.
CS 4400.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of D
CS 4400.title: Intr to Database Systems

CS 4420.description: Study of fundamental software components/algorithms of a database system, including the file manager, query engine, lock manager, and recovery manager. Includes a project component. Credit not allowed for both CS 4420 and CS 6422.
CS 4420.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4420.title: Database Sys Implement

CS 4432.description: The analysis, design, and implementation of information systems. Topics include requirements analysis, design representations, implementation techniques, and evaluation of systems.
CS 4432.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3300 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4432.title: Information Systems Dsgn

CS 4440.description: The course will cover current developments including distributed, object-oriented, temporal-spatial, Web-based, mobile, and active database technologies, and data warehousing and mining applications.
CS 4440.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4440.title: Database Technologies

CS 4452.description: Introduction to programming and human-centered principles of computing based on a communications and media computation context. Introduces user interface programming. Credit not awarded for both CS 4452 and CS 1315.
CS 4452.title: Human-Centered Computing

CS 4455.description: Techniques for electronic game design and programming, including graphics game engines, motion generation, behavioral control for autonomous characters, interaction structure, social and interface issues of multi-user play, and the business aspects of game development. Credit not allowed for both CS 4455 and CS 6457.
CS 4455.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3451 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4455.title: Video Game Design

CS 4460.description: Introduction to principles and techniques of infomation visualization, the presentation of primarily abstract data to help people understand, analyze and make sense of data. Students will not receive credit for both CS 4460 and CS 7450.
CS 4460.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1332 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4460.title: Intro Info Visualization

CS 4460R.description: This recitation supports the information visualization (CS 4460) course. Sessions will focus on introducing students to technical work with visualization programming languages and grammars important to the course.
CS 4460R.title: CS 4460 Recitation

CS 4464.description: A study of computational and technological advancements in journalism with emphasis on technologies for developing new tools and their potential impact on news and information. Credit not allowed for both CS 4464 and CS 6465.
CS 4464.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4464.title: Computational Journalism

CS 4470.description: Concepts, techniques, structures, and strategies for implementation of interactive software. Credit not awarded for both CS 4470 and CS 6456.
CS 4470.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of C and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 3750 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level PSYC 3750 Minimum Grade of C)
CS 4470.title: User Interface Software

CS 4472.description: Introduction to the design of online communities. Students study an existing community in depth. Credit not allowed for both CS 4472 and CS 6470.
CS 4472.title: Design of Online Comm

CS 4475.description: An introductory course on the scientific, technical, perceptual, and aesthetic principles of pictures. Emphasis is on the techniques of image formation, analysis, merging, modification and their use for depiction of reality on a 2D medium of photographs.
CS 4475.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1301 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1315 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 1371 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4475.title: Comp Photography

CS 4476.description: Introduction to computer vision including fundamentals of image formation, camera imaging geometry, feature detection and matching, stereo, motion estimation and tracking, image classification and scene understanding. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4476 and CS 4495 or CS 6476.
CS 4476.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2605 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2401 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 24X1 Minimum Grade of T or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2411 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1553 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1X54 Minimum Grade of T or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1554 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1564 Minimum Grade of D) and ( (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of C) or (Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2020 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2035 Minimum Grade of C) )
CS 4476.title: Intro to Computer Vision

CS 4480.description: A study of digital multimedia and the analysis and synthesis of digital video. Special attention paid to techniques for generating video special effects.
CS 4480.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3451 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4480.title: Digital Video Special FX

CS 4495.description: An introduction to computer vision and machine perception. An intensive study of the process of generating a symbolic description of the scene by interpretation of images(s).
CS 4495.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2605 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2401 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 24X1 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2411 Minimum Grade of D) and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of C)
CS 4495.title: Computer Vision

CS 4496.description: Motion techniques for computer animation and interactive games (keyframing, procedural methods, motion capture, and simulation) and principles for storytelling, composition, lighting, and interactivity.
CS 4496.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3451 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4496.title: Computer Animation

CS 4497.description: Aesthetics plays a key role in society and economy. Students will invent and test beautification algorithms for colors, music, and animations and more.
CS 4497.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3451 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4497.title: Comp Aesthetics

CS 4510.description: Computational machine models and their language classes. Undecidability. Resource-bounded computations. Central complexity-theoretic concepts such as complexity classes, reducibility and completeness.
CS 4510.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 3511 Minimum Grade of C) and (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3012 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3022 Minimum Grade of D) and (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3215 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3235 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3225 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3770 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 3670 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CEE 3770 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 3770 Minimum Grade of D or (Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 2027 Minimum Grade of D and Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 2028 Minimum Grade of D) )
CS 4510.title: Automata and Complexity

CS 4520.description: Approximation algorithms for NP-hard optimization problems, design and analysis techniques for such algorithms. Credit not allowed for both CS 4520 and CS 7520.
CS 4520.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4540 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4520.title: Approximation Algs

CS 4530.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4540 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4530.title: Randomized Algs

CS 4540.description: Advanced techniques for designing and analyzing efficient algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number theoretic problems. Credit not allowed for both CS 4540 and CS 6505 or CS 4540 and CS 6515.

CS 4550.description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient transmission, analysis, filtering, and visualization of large scientific data sets.
CS 4550.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3451 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4550.title: Scientific Visualization

CS 4560.description: Technique for verifying, validating and testing software and hardware systems. Topics covered will include modeling, abstraction methods, evaluation and certification, and computer-aided verification methods.
CS 4560.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1050 Minimum Grade of C and Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4560.title: Verification of Systems

CS 4590.description: A well-rounded exploration of digital audio and its importance in current research and applications. Exposes students to the principles, technology, and current research of computer audio.
CS 4590.title: Computer Audio

CS 4605.description: Investigates the infrastructure required to develop mobile and ubiquitous computing applications and establishes major research themes and experimental practices.Credit not awarded for both CS 4605 and CS 7470.

CS 4611.description: Basic concepts and methods of AI problem solving, knowledge representation, reasoning, and learning.

CS 4611.title: AI Problem Solving

CS 4613.description: Techniques for constructing large knowledge-based systems. Advanced symbolic AI techniques. Constraint systems.
CS 4613.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3600 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4613.title: Knowledge Systems Engr

CS 4615.description: Information-processing theories of modeling and design; topics include design decision-making, problem-solving and learning, and knowledge-based modeling and design.

CS 4616.description: An introductory course on pattern classification and decision problems with applications to character recognition, image analysis, and speech recognition.
CS 4616.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4616.title: Pattern Recognition

CS 4622.description: Based on human problem-solving, CBR has had many successes in industry and research. Topics include case representation, indexing and retrieval, similarity assessment, adaptation, learning. Credit not allowed for both CS 4622 and CS 7620.
CS 4622.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3600 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4622.title: Case-Based Reasoning

CS 4625.description: Explores how human-computer interaction and machine learning can interact to create personalized information environments. Emphasis on current research efforts from both fields.
CS 4625.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4625.title: Intel & Interactive Sys

CS 4632.description: Hands-on course in which students program autonomous mobile robots and solve complex tasks for robot teams.
CS 4632.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3630 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4632.title: Adv Intelligent Robotics

CS 4635.description: Structured knowledge representation; knowledge-based methods of reasoning and learning; problem-solving, modeling and design.
CS 4635.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3600 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4635.title: Knowledge-Based AI

CS 4641.description: Machine learning techniques and applications. Topics include foundational issues; inductive, analytical, numerical, and theoretical approaches; and real-world applications. Credit not awarded for both CS 4641 and CS 7641/CSE 6740/ISYE 6740.
CS 4641.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4641.title: Machine Learning

CS 4644.description: This course will cover the fundamental underpinnings and practice of deep learning, including neural network architectures, optimization algorithms, and applications to perception and Artificial Intelligence.
CS 4644.prereqs: (Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2605 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2401 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 24X1 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2411 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2550 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2551 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2561 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 2X51 Minimum Grade of D) and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of D) and (Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 3511 Minimum Grade of D)

CS 4646.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3600 Minimum Grade of C

CS 4649.description: We investigate algorithms for robots and complex systems that make intelligent decisions. Emphasis on the theoretical and empirical properties of classical, geometric, stochastic/dynamic planning.

CS 4650.description: Methodologies for designing systems that comprehend natural language. Topics include lexical analysis, parsing, interpretation of sentences, semantic representation, organization of knowledge, and inference mechanisms. Credit not allowed for both CS 4650 and CS 7650.
CS 4650.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 3511 Minimum Grade of C

CS 4660.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of educational technology. Covers learning theory applicable to educational technology, explains major research findings. Credit not awarded for both CS 4660 and CS 6460.

CS 4665.title: Educ Tech: Dsgn & Eval

CS 4670.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4660 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4670.title: CSCL

CS 4675.description: Focusing on fundamental issues, concepts, techniques, and technical challenges that are critical for designing and developing Internet systems, services and applications. Credit not allowed for both CS 4675 and CS 6675.
CS 4675.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 3057 Minimum Grade of C

CS 4690.description: Introduction to empirical methods for gathering requirements and evaluating the end-user and usability of software systems.
CS 4690.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3750 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level PSYC 3750 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4690.title: Empirical Methods in HCI

CS 4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CS 4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CS 4723.description: Entrepreneurial Junior Design. Teams comprised of CS, ECE, and ME students will design and build prototypes of their invention ideas and explore market fit.

CS 4725.title: Info Security Policies

CS 4726.description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to privacy, a topic of great interest in the technology, policy, ethics, law, and business realms. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4726 and MGT 4726 or MGT 6726 or CS 6726.
CS 4726.title: Privacy Tech Policy Law

CS 4731.description: Examines the expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games. Students learn AI programming techniques, and how they strongly interface with game design.
CS 4731.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3600 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4731.title: Game AI

CS 4741.description: Individual and group-based experiential learning activities to develop integrated human system management skills that prepare students for more successful capstone collaboration and learning. Credit not allowed for both CS 4741 and MGT 4741 or ME 4741.

A different integrative project or set of projects will be taken on each semester; students will contribute on the basis of their background and skill. Crosslisted with PST, PSYC, and ISYE 4791.

CS 4793.description: An integrative course in cognitive science which uses a focus topic to deepen interdisciplinary perspective and develop cognitive science knowledge and skills.
CS 4793.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3790 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level PST 3790 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level PSYC 3790 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ISYE 3790 Minimum Grade of C
CS 4793.title: Perspectives-Cog Science

CS 4795.description: 3-D graphics pipelines. Physically-based rendering. Game engine architectures. GPU architectures. Graphics APIs. Vertex and pixel shader programming. Post-processing effects. Deferred rendering.
CS 4795.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2035 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level ECE 2036 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2110 Minimum Grade of C or Undergraduate Semester level CS 2261 Minimum Grade of C

CS 6010.description: This is an interactive hands-on course that will teach students the principles of design at the individual level.

CS 6035.description: A broad spectrum of information security: threats, basic cryptography, software vulnerabilities, programming for malice, operating system protections, network security, privacy, data mining, computer crime.

CS 6035.title: Intro To Info Security

CS 6235.title: Real-Time Systems

CS 6238.title: Secure Computer Systems

CS 6241.description: Design and implementation of modern compilers, focusing upon optimization and code generation.
CS 6241.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4240 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6241.title: Compiler Design

CS 6245.description: Design and implementation of compilers for parallel and distributed computers, focusing upon optimization and code generation.
CS 6245.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4240 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6245.title: Parallelizing Compilers

CS 6246.description: Design and implementation of object-oriented systems. Aspect-oriented programming, type systems, OO language implementation (virtual dispatch, GC), OO language design (genericity, reflection, mixins).
CS 6246.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2340 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6246.title: Object-Oriented Systems

CS 6250.description: Principles and practice of computer networks, including signaling and framing, error control, medium access, routing, congestion control, end-to-end transport, and network APIs.

CS 6255.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6250 Minimum Grade of D

CS 6260.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4235 Minimum Grade of D

CS 6262.title: Network Security

CS 6263.description: This course provides an introduction to security issues relating to various cyber-physical systems including industrial control systems and those considered critical infrastructure systems.

CS 6264.description: This course will help students develop both in-depth knowledge and hands-on skills in a number of important cybersecurity areas, including software security, malware and threat analysis, end-point security, network security, web security, mobile security, and machine learning based security analytics.

CS 6265.description: This course covers advanced techniques for writing exploits, taught through an intense, hands-on security laboratory, following a cyberspace war game called Capture-The-Flag.
CS 6265.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6238 Minimum Grade of D and Graduate Semester level CS 6262 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6265.title: Info Sec Lab Binexp

CS 6266.description: Capstone independent study placing each student in a commercial, industrial, academic, or government setting where they must solve real-world security problems.
CS 6266.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6238 Minimum Grade of D and Graduate Semester level CS 6260 Minimum Grade of D and Graduate Semester level CS 6262 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6266.title: Info Security Practicum

CS 6269.description: Logical foundations of high-assurance systems, formal models for access control, authentication, and trust; techniques for constructing high-assurance systems.
CS 6269.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3500 Minimum Grade of D and Undergraduate Semester level CS 4235 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6269.title: Formal Info Assur Model

CS 6280.title: Eval Communication Nets

CS 6290.description: Topics concerning very high-performance computers including techniques exploiting parallelism in single and multiple processor systems. Credit not allowed for both CS 6290 and any of the following courses: CS 4290, ECE 4100, ECE 6100.
CS 6290.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2200 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6290.title: High Perform Comput Arch

CS 6291.description: First, this course introduces the student to embedded domain-specific processor and instruction set design issues. Next, machine-specific optimizations for performance and for energy consumption are discussed.
CS 6291.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4290 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6291.title: Embedded Software Opt.

CS 6300.description: The process of developing software systems. Includes development and assessment of processes, their instantiation in actual product development, and techniques ensuring quality of developed products.

CS 6301.description: This project-based course will cover fundamental principles, advanced techniques, and tools for the development of high-quality, industrial-strength software.

CS 6310.description: Principles and concepts involved in the design and analysis of large software systems.
CS 6310.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6300 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6310.title: Software Arch & Design

CS 6320.description: Methods and principles for determining, documenting, analyzing, and formally specifying requirements for software systems.
CS 6320.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6300 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6320.title: Requirements Analysis

CS 6330.description: Introduction to methods and principles for programming, testing, and managing the evolution of software systems.
CS 6330.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6300 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6330.title: Software Generation&Test

CS 6340.description: Fundamental prinicples and advanced techniques for static and dynamic program analysis and software testing. Software reliability, resilience, and trustworthiness.
CS 6340.title: Software Analysis & Test

CS 6365.description: Survey of basic software concepts and techniques used in mission-critical systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying enterprise computing. Credit not allowed for both CS 6365 and CS 4365.
CS 6365.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3210 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6365.title: Intro Enterprise Comput.

CS 6390.description: Design, structure, and goals of programming languages. Object-oriented, logic, functional, and traditional languages. Semantic models. Parallel programming languages.
CS 6390.title: Programming Languages

CS 6400.description: Study of fundamental concepts with regard to relational databases. Topics covered include database design, query processing, concurrency control, and recovery. Credit not given for both CS 6400 and CS 6754.
CS 6400.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6400.title: DB Sys Concepts& Design

CS 6402.description: Fundamentals of designing and using databases: conceptual data models to database-specific models, SQL, storage structures. Security-related topics include privacy, access control, backup, recovery, SQL injection. Credit not allowed for both CS 6402 and CS 4400.
CS 6402.title: Databases and Infosec

CS 6411.description: Study of advanced database concepts as they apply to object-oriented database systems. Topics include semantic data models, object-oriented query languages, tools, and applications.
CS 6411.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6411.title: O-O Database Model & Sys

CS 6421.description: Study of advanced database concepts for temporal databases with emphasis on storage structure, processing and query languages, as well as active database concepts and implementation.
CS 6421.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6421.title: Tempor,Spatial&Active DB

CS 6422.description: Design and implementatuion of a databse system covering: storage manager, query optimizer, transaction manager, and recovery manager. Study of the advantages of different implementation algorithms. Credit not allowed for both CS 6422 and CS 4420.
CS 6422.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6422.title: Database System Implemnt

CS 6430.description: Study of algorithms and performance in advanced databases. Systems include parallel, distributed, and client-server databases. Applications include data mining and on-line analytical processing.
CS 6430.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4420 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 6400 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6430.title: Parallel&Distributed DB

CS 6440.description: A broad review of the US health system and the application of informatics to the clinical practice of medicine, digital imaging, public health and bioinformatics.
CS 6440.title: Intro Health Informatics

CS 6451.description: Introduction to the range of issues across the HCC disciplines, including design and research methodologies: cognitive, social, and cultural theories; assessment and evaluation: ethical issues.
CS 6451.title: Human-Centered Computing

CS 6452.description: Introduction to design, prototyping and implementation of systems for human-centered computing. Focuses on core concepts in computer science and implications for interactive systems.
CS 6452.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4452 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6452.title: Prototyping Interact Sys

CS 6454.description: Qualitative methods for HCI including data collection through interviews, observations and design, analysis using research and industry standards, and methods for communicating findings to industry.
CS 6454.title: Qualitative Methods HCI

CS 6455.description: Examines usability in the software development process with an emphasis on usability, requirements, methodology, design, and evaluation.
CS 6455.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6750 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level PSYC 6750 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6455.title: User Interface Dsgn&Eval

CS 6456.description: Considers the architectural and algorithmic principles behind the implementation of interactive software systems and the tools that support them. Credit not awarded for CS 6456 and CS 4470.
CS 6456.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6750 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level PSYC 6750 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6456.title: Principles-UI Software

CS 6457.description: Techniques for electronic game design and programming, including graphics, game engines, animation, behavioral control for autonomous characters, interaction, social and interface issues of multi-user play. Credit not allowed for both CS 6457 and CS 4455.
CS 6457.title: Video Game Design

CS 6460.description: Introduction to educational technology, with an emphasis on theoretical foundations. Introduces basic philosophies, approaches, and technologies. Analyzes issues surrounding technology's impact on education. Credit not awarded for both CS 4660 and CS 6460.
CS 6460.title: Educ Tech-Foundations

CS 6461.description: Introduction to computing education research (CER). History and influential early work. Learning goals for different populations. Design of research studies in CER.
CS 6461.title: Computing Ed Research

CS 6465.description: Technology is rapidly affecting how news information is gathered, reported, visualized, aggregated, summarized, distributed, and consumed. This class studies the computational technologies that impact journalism. Credit not allowed for both CS 6455 and CS 4464.
CS 6465.title: Computational Journalism

CS 6470.description: Introduction to the design of online communities. Students study an existing community in depth, and then develop a new community design. Credit not allowed for both CS 6470 and CS 4472.
CS 6470.title: Online Communities

CS 6471.description: This graduate seminar focuses on text and network analysis of data with applications to domains such as political science, sociolinguistics, and public health.
CS 6471.title: Comp Social Science

CS 6474.description: Design and prototype new social computing systems, as well as analyze social media data.

CS 6475.description: This class explores the impact of computation on the entire workflow of photography, from how light is captured by a camera, to how the images are processed, enhanced, and improved to generate novel photographs.
CS 6475.title: Comp. Photography

CS 6476.description: Introduction to computer vision including fundamentals of image formation, camera imaging geometry, feature detection and matching, stereo, motion estimation and tracking, image classification and scene understanding. Credit not awarded for both CS 6476 and CS 4495 or CS 4476.
CS 6476.title: Computer Vision

CS 6480.description: Principles, techniques, and practice in data, information, multivariate, and scientific visualization. Includes visualization methods, data structures, examples, and tools.
CS 6480.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4451 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6480.title: Comp Visualiz Techniques

CS 6485.description: Algorithms, software, and practical applications of visualization techniques in science, engineering, business, and medicine. Includes data structures, multivariate visualization, interactive visualization, and visual representations and examples. Computer science students cannot receive credit for this course.
CS 6485.title: Visual Meth-Sci & Engr

CS 6491.description: Mathematical/physical/perceptual principles and modeling/rendering techniques used to create, represent, display, and animate models of 3D shapes and their properties.
CS 6491.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4451 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6491.title: Computer Graphics

CS 6497.description: Aesthetics play a key role in society and economy. Students will invent and test beautification algorithms for colors, music, and animations and more.
CS 6497.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6491 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6497.title: Comp Aesthetics

CS 6505.description: Important concepts from computability theory; techniques for designing algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number-theoretic problems; basic concepts such as NP-Completeness from computational complexity theory. Credit not awarded for both CS 6505 and CS 4540/6515.
CS 6505.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6505.title: Computability&Algorithms

CS 6515.description: Design and analysis of algorithms on a graduate level, including dynamic programming, divide and conquer, FFT, graph and flow algorithms, RSA, linear programming, and NP-completedness.
CS 6515.title: Intro to Grad Algorithms

CS 6520.description: Introduction to resource-bounded computations, central complexity-theoretic concepts such as complexity classes, reducibility, completeness, and intractability.
CS 6520.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3500 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6520.title: Computational Complexity

CS 6550.description: Advanced techniques for designing and analyzing efficient algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number-theoretic problems.
CS 6550.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3500 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6550.title: Design& Analy-Algorithms

CS 6601.description: Basic concepts and methods of artificial intelligence including both symbolic/conceptual and numerical/probabilistic techniques.
CS 6601.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 2600 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6601.title: Artificial Intelligence

CS 6603.description: This course covers various Artificial Intelligence and bias mitigation techniques that can be used to counterbalance the potential misuse and abuse of learning from data.
CS 6603.title: AI Ethics Society

CS 6670.description: Algorithms for synchronous, asynchronous, and partially synchronous networks; analysis, control, and implementation of distributed systems such as robot fleets, animal groups.
CS 6670.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4600 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6670.title: Distrib Cntrl Algorithms

CS 6675.description: Survey of basic Internet computing concepts and techniques used in Internet systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying Internet computing. Credit not allowed for both CS 6675 and CS 4675.
CS 6675.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 3210 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 4499 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6675.title: Advance Internet Comput

CS 6705.description: A study of the principles and practice of artificial intelligence in areas other than computer science, with particular focus on engineering, science, and business applications. Computer science majors cannot receive credit for this course.
CS 6705.title: Applications of AI

CS 6725.description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks; legal, cost, privacy, and technology constraints; derivation of strategies; technical and procedural means of achieving desired ends. Credit not awarded for both CS 6725 and CS 4725/MGT 4725/6725/PUBP 4725/6725.
CS 6725.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4235 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6725.title: Info Security Policies

CS 6726.description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to privacy, a topic of great interest in the technology, policy, ethics, law, and business realms. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 6726 and CS 4726 or MGT 4726 or MGT 6726.
CS 6726.title: Privacy Tech Policy Law

CS 6727.description: Capstone independent study project placing each student in a commercial, academic or government setting where he or she identifies a major cyber security problem, and explores and evaluates a solution that addresses it with realistic assumptions about the organizational context. The chose problem must be approved by course instructor. Cross-listed with ECE and PUBP 6727.
CS 6727.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 6035 Minimum Grade of D and (Undergraduate Semester level PUBP 6725 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level CS 6725 Minimum Grade of D)
CS 6727.title: Cyber Sec Practicum

CS 6730.description: Introductory course on design principles and applications of data visualization. This course teaches best practices for visualizing datasets from diverse domains intended to help people make sense of data.
CS 6730.title: Data Vis Principles

CS 6745.description: Focus on technology design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.
CS 6745.title: Info&Com Tech&Global Dev

CS 6747.description: This course covers advanced approaches for the analysis of malicious software and explores recent research and unsolved problems in software protection and forensics.
CS 6747.title: ADV Malware Analysis

CS 6750.description: Describes the characteristics of interaction between humans and computers and demonstrates techniques for the evaluation of user-centered systems. Crosslisted with PSYC 6750.
CS 6750.title: Human-Computer Interact

CS 6753.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.
CS 6753.title: HCI Prof Prep & Practice

CS 6754.description: Modeling and managing engineering information systems, integration of design and manufacturing functions in engineering product development, logical models of engineering product and processes. Credit not given for CS 6400 and CS 6754. Crosslisted with ME 6754.
CS 6754.title: Engr Database Mgt System

CS 6755.description: Describes the theory and practice of designing effective and efficient interactions between people and technology. Students do not receive credit for both CS 6755 and PSYC 6755.
CS 6755.title: HCI Foundations

CS 6763.description: Analysis of design processes; analysis of current design tools at both the user interface and functional levels; procedures for developing better design tools. Credit not allowed for both CS 6763 and ID 6763 or COA 6763.
CS 6763.title: Design of Environments

CS 6764.description: Software development course focusing on 3D geometric constructions and modeling; emphasizes solid modeling and its role in design. Crosslisted with COA 6764.
CS 6764.title: Geometric Modeling

CS 6770.description: Introduction to the design of Mixed Reality experiences. Focuses on informal design, integration of media theory, HCI and technology issues. Significant group design projects.Credit not awarded for both CS 6770 and CS 4770/LMC 4733/6340.
CS 6770.title: Mixed Reality Design

CS 6780.description: A study of methods for enhancing, analyzing, interpreting, and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical image modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and BMED 6780.
CS 6780.prereqs: Graduate Semester level ECE 6786 Minimum Grade of D or Graduate Semester level BMED 6786 Minimum Grade of D
CS 6780.title: Medical Image Processing

CS 6795.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with ISYE and PSYC 6795.
CS 6795.title: Intro-Cognitive Science

CS 6998.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.
CS 6998.title: HCI Master's Project

CS 6999.description: Final project for students completing a master's degree in the College of Computing. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.
CS 6999.title: Master's Project

CS 7000.description: Master's Thesis Prerequisite: consent of the College.
CS 7000.title: Master's Thesis

CS 7001.description: Research tools including computer systems, as well as fundamental problem-solving skills, are introduced. Lectures on current computing research are presented and projects are required. Credit not allowed in a program of study for a graduate degree.
CS 7001.title: Grad Studies-Computing

CS 7110.description: Issues in the design, implementation, and programming of parallel machines. Credit not allowed for both CS 7110 and CS 4233.
CS 7110.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6290 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7110.title: Parallel Computer Arch

CS 7210.description: Fundamental concepts in distributed systems, including global states, logical clocks, and failure models. Distributed algorithms and their implementations using advanced distributed programming systems.
CS 7210.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6210 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7210.title: Distributed Computing

CS 7230.description: Design, implementation, and evaluation of systems software. Distributed/parallel applications will be constructed and evaluated using the systems support that is developed.
CS 7230.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4240 Minimum Grade of D and Graduate Semester level CS 6210 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7230.title: Software Dsgn,Impl& Eval

CS 7250.description: Focus on the data link layer and its relationship to layers below and above. Gigabit Ethernet, SONTET, fibre channel; media including wireless, satellite, xDSL, cable.
CS 7250.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6250 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7250.title: Broadband Networking Sys

CS 7260.description: Detailed discussion of the problems and solution techniques that arise in internetworking. Topics include routing, addressing, quality of service, and security.
CS 7260.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6250 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7260.title: Internet Arch& Protocols

CS 7270.description: End-to-end functional building blocks and their use in adaptive and non-adaptive applications, including multimedia: coding, compression, security, directory services.
CS 7270.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6250 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7270.title: Networked Apps&Services

CS 7280.description: Characteristics of real networks in nature and technology, network measurement methods, network analysis, evolving networks, dynamic network processes, co-evolution of structure and function.
CS 7280.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1554 Minimum Grade of D or Undergraduate Semester level MATH 1564 Minimum Grade of D and Undergraduate Semester level CS 1331 Minimum Grade of D and Undergraduate Semester level CS 3510 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7280.title: Network Science

CS 7290.description: Low-level organization and hardware algorithms for the implementation of modern high-performance microprocessors including concept designs and real-world case studies.
CS 7290.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6290 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7290.title: Adv. Microarchitecture

CS 7292.description: Hardware support for process isolation, virtualization, debugging, and protection from side-channel attacks. Faults and failures, error tolerance, error rate budgeting, lifetime realiability of devices.
CS 7292.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6290 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7292.title: Reliable Secure Comparch

CS 7450.description: Study of computer visualization principles, techniques, and tools used for explaining and understanding symbolic, structured, and/or hierarchical information. Includes data and software visualization. Students cannot receive credit for both CS 7450 and CS 4460.
CS 7450.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6750 Minimum Grade of D or Graduate Semester level PSYC 6750 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7450.title: Inform Visualization

CS 7451.description: This course covers the role of people in data science and visual data analysis, including cognitive processes, bias, perception, and decision-making theories and frameworks.
CS 7451.title: Hum-Center Data Analysis

CS 7455.description: In-depth focus on theoretical, methodological, conceptual, and technical issues across the HCC disciplines associated with humans (cognitive, biological, socio-cultural); design; ethics; and analysis and evaluation.
CS 7455.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6452 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7455.title: Issues/Human-Center Comp

CS 7460.description: Introduction to computer-supported collaborative work, workflow automation, and meeting augmentation. The course deals with models, enabling technology, systems, and applications.
CS 7460.title: Collaborative Computing

CS 7465.description: Intensive project class in which students design, implement, and evaluate a piece of educational technology, applying the theory learned in Educational Technology: Conceptual Foundations.
CS 7465.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6460 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7465.title: Edu Tech-Design and Eval

CS 7467.description: Computer-supported collaborative learning is the use of Internet-based technologies to support learning in social settings. Focus on issues of implementation and evaluation.
CS 7467.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6460 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7467.title: Comp Collaborative Learn

CS 7476.description: Advanced topics in computer vision, which includes a deep dive into both the theoretical foundations of computer vision to the practical issues of building real systems that use computer vision. Credit will not be awarded for CS 7476 and CS 7495.
CS 7476.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6476 Minimum Grade of D

CS 7490.description: Advanced techniques in realistic image synthesis based on the physics of light. Anti-aliasing, textures, surface reflectance, distribution ray tracing, volume rendering, radiosity, and image-based rendering.

CS 7491.description: Multiresolution, compression, collision, morphing, visibility, and computational geometry techniques for accessing, rendering, and animating complex 3D models in engineering, scientific, business, or entertainment applications.
CS 7491.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6491 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7491.title: 3D Complexity

CS 7492.description: Study different computer simulation methods for use in investigating biological systems, including bio-molecules, cells and full organisms.
CS 7492.title: Simulation of Biology

CS 7495.description: An introduction to computer vision and machine perception. An intensive study of the process of generating a symbolic description of the scene by interpretation of images(s). Credit will not be awarded for both CS 7495 and CS 7476.

CS 7496.description: Motion techniques for computer animation and interactive games (keyframing, procedural methods, motion capture, and simulation) and principles for storytelling, composition, lighting, and interactivity.
CS 7496.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4451 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7496.title: Computer Animation

CS 7497.description: An introduction to virtual reality and virtual environments. Issues covered will include VR technology, software design, 3D human-computer interaction, and applications for VR.
CS 7497.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4451 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7497.title: Virtual Environments

CS 7510.title: Graph Algorithm

CS 7520.description: Approximation algorithms for NP-hard optimization problems, design and analysis techniques for such algorithms. Credit not allowed for both CS 7520 and CS 4520.
CS 7520.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6505 Minimum Grade of D or Graduate Semester level CS 6550 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7520.title: Approximation Algorithms

CS 7525.description: Algorithmic aspects of game theory covering topics at the intersection of computer science, economics, and game theory with applications to domains such as internet.
CS 7525.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6550 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7525.title: Algorithmic Game Theory

CS 7530.description: Techniques for designing and analyzing randomized algorithms, derandomization techniques. Credit not allowed for both CS 7530 and CS 4530.
CS 7530.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6505 Minimum Grade of D or Graduate Semester level CS 6550 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7530.title: Randomized Algorithms

CS 7535.description: This course studies Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms, widely-used in a variety of scientific fields, focusing on mathematical techniques for analyzing their convergence rates.
CS 7535.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6505 Minimum Grade of D or Graduate Semester level CS 6550 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7535.title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo

CS 7540.description: Spectral methods mathematics and algorithmic insights driving applications with large data sets in domains such as web-search, information-retrieval, and medical diagnosis and prediction.

CS 7545.description: This course provides a basic arsenal of powerful mathematical tools for the analysis of learning algorithms, focusing on both statistical and computational aspects.
CS 7545.title: Machine Learning Theory

CS 7560.description: One-way functions, pseudorandomness, public-key and identity-based cryptography, commitment and zero knowledge.

CS 7610.description: Information-processing theories of modeling and design; topics include design decision making, problem solving and learning, and knowledge-based modeling and design.
CS 7610.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 4600 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7610.title: Modeling and Design

CS 7611.description: Basic concepts and methods of AI problem solving, knowledge representation, reasoning, and learning.
CS 7611.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6601 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7611.title: AI Problem Solving

CS 7612.description: Symbolic numerical techniques that allow intelligent systems to decide how they should act in order to achieve their goals, including action and plan representation, plan synthesis and reasoning, analysis of planning algorithms, plan execution and monitoring, plan reuse and learning, and applications.
CS 7612.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6601 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7612.title: AI Planning

CS 7613.description: Techniques for constructing large knowledge-based systems. Advanced symbolic AI techniques. Constraint systems.
CS 7613.prereqs: Graduate Semester level CS 6601 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7613.title: Knowledge Systems Engr

CS 7615.description: Knowledge-based interactive systems, knowledge-based autonomous agents, agent architectures, learning and adaptation, agent evolution.
CS 7615.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4600 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7615.title: Knowledge Agents

CS 7616.description: This course provides an introduction to the theory and practice of pattern recognition. It emphasizes unifying concepts and the analysis of real-world datasets.

CS 7620.description: Topics include case representation, indexing and retrieval, adaptation, interpretive CBR, the cognitive model that CBR implies, and its implications for creativity, decision aiding, and education. Credit not allowed for both CS 7620 and CS 4622.
CS 7620.prereqs: Undergraduate Semester level CS 4600 Minimum Grade of D
CS 7620.title: Case-Based Reasoning

CS 7626.description: An introduction to the use of sensor data and machine learning methods to measure and model human behavior objectively and automatically for health applications.

CS 7633.description: Survey of the state of the art in HRI research, introduction to statistical methods for HRI research, research project studio.

CS 7634.description: An exploration of how artificial intelligence can enable us to use stories in virtual worlds for the purpose of entertaining, educatintg, and training human users.

Newer approaches combining statistical language processing and information retrieval techniques. Credit not allowed for both CS 7650 and CS 4650.
